Award.AwardTitle: Fabrication of Double-Layer Cellular Spheroid using Acoustic Excitation-Assisted Compound Jetting

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this study is to test the hypothesis that the formability of viable double-layer cellular spheroids during acoustic excitation-assisted compound jetting can be predicted using scale analysis and a method-of-line numerical approach. The proposed research activities involve: 1) development of an acoustic excitation-based compound jetting apparatus with imaging capability, 2) modeling and validation of the double-layer cellular spheroid fabrication process using scale analysis and numerical simulations, and 3) size and viability evaluation of fabricated cellular spheroids. In this proposed compound jetting system, concentric core fluid (cell suspension), shell fluid (sodium alginate) and carrier stream (air) jets break into double-layer core-shell structure microcapsules under the effect of acoustic excitation.

This study will contribute to biofabrication technology. Specifically, controllable fabrication of double-layer cellular spheroids will lead to robust organ printing, enabling on-demand organ manufacturing and other microcapsule-related healthcare technologies such as drug delivery. Broader impacts also include a pipeline of well trained, motivated students ready to undertake careers in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics disciplines through various summer programs for research interns and promote the biomedical manufacturing curriculum development.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organ printing is the bottom-up rapid prototyping of complex cellular organization of native tissues or organs through the three-dimensional bioprinting of multiple cell types and other biomaterials at designated positions. The rising success rate of transplants has resulted in a critical need for more tissues and organs. There are currently more than 120,000 people waiting for organ donations and only 14,000 donors. Many patients die before an organ becomes available for transplantation, unfortunately. Integrated with a better understanding of multicellular self-assembly, bioprinting-based organ fabrication provides a promising solution to the organ donor shortage. While some major challenges in organ printing are biological, the scale-up of manufacturing processes to produce viable constructs is also critical; the first step towards successful organ printing is to generate multi-layered cellular droplets/spheroids and further use them for construct fabrication, which is the subject of this study.

The study has resulted in new knowledge of the effects of external excitation and electric field on the droplet formation process during drop-on-demand inkjetting; the effects of material properties and operating conditions on the pinch-off location, which may be classified as front pinching, hybrid pinching, exit pinching, or middle pinching, also during drop-on-demand inkjetting; and the formation conditions for multi-layered microcapsules when using coaxial nozzle jetting. Specifically, a linear instability analysis has been used to define the perturbation growth rates of stretching and squeezing modes and the growth ratio as a function of the wavenumber. In addition, a computational fluid dynamics method has been implemented to model the microcapsule formation process in order to determine the processing window for good microcapsule formation based on the growth ratio curve during compound jetting. The lower and upper bounds of the good microcapsule processing window can be determined using a pseudo-bisection method based on both the stretching and squeezing modes for a given material-nozzle system.

The resulting droplet formation knowledge has been further applied to successfully fabricate three-dimensional zigzag and bifurcated cellular tubes, which are dispensable for living thick tissues and organs. By implementing a deformation compensation and liquid support-based approach, fibroblast-based vascular-like structures with both horizontal and vertical branching features have been successfully printed. This represents the first successful freeform fabrication of multidirectional branching vascular-like structures. This study will promote the further development of envisioned organ printing, providing a promising tool for the on-demand fabrication of tissue engineered substitutes, which may be used for customized implantation and as in vitro models for disease detection and drug screening, to name a few. In addition, four graduate students including an underrepresented graduate student have been trained in the course of this research study, and the resulting knowledge has been integrated in offering a graduate-level advanced manufacturing course.


Last Modified: 11/28/2016
Modified by: Yong Huang

The rising success rate of transplants has resulted in a critical need for more tissues and organs. There are currently more than 120,000 people waiting for organ donations and only 14,000 donors. Many patients die before an organ becomes available for transplantation, unfortunately.
